reviewText: One doesn't expect 18th century French Opera to be so much darn fun! This is one of those clever productions where most of the money got spent on costumes and the barest minimum of sets so the director's talents and abilities are on full display bringing us a witty, inventive, surprising and always delightful show that embraces the music with superb musicianship and visual joy. Everyone in the cast is apparently having the time of their lives and their own enjoyment in the proceedings is infectious. It's easy to fall in love with Rameau's music. The quality of writing is a sheer joy for this delightful divertisement. Captures both the witty sophistication of it's time and shows us how it's done in our own. This opens a whole new world of art to explore. Bon Voyage!

reviewerName: Dr. John W. Rippon "May 19, 1932 and still going"
reviewText: Platee by Jean-Philippe Rameau. Silly! One word summarizes this work of the ancien regime to a 21st century audience. Were it not by a master composer of the Baroque, Jean-Philippe Rameau, it would have remained lost in the dust of time. Rameau's operas were so identified with the age of Louis XV that post-revolutionary France found no place for their myths, heroes and aristocrats. Simpler stories and the more direct Italian buffa style replaced the artificialities of Rameau and his colleagues at the Academie Royale de Musique under the aegis of the "querelle de buffons". Yet Handel operas now have outlived his era as have those of Monteverdi and Gluck. So why are the operas of Rameau, so full of great music, so moribund? As opera historian Donald Grout indicates, his limited success is attributable to poor quality of his librettos and is a classic example of great music forgotten because it cannot be detached from a dead operatic style encumbered by so many conventions of a bygone era.The revival of interest in Baroque music and opera of the last several decades has seen many overlooked works resurrected: Handel, of course, but also Vivaldi, Cavalli, Lully and some Rameau. Rameau is considered a superior musician to Lully and his music is more violent and dramatic than the older master. When he could find a good libretto such as Les Indes Galantes the outcome is a masterpiece that has remained alive. The successful revival of Les Boreades (a truly magical work) and Zoroastre both by the same librettist de Cahusac shows that there are some gems among his twenty or so works he wrote for the theater.Platee is an opera-ballet of 1745 to a patched-up libretto by le Valois d'Orville after a farce by J. Autreau. It is not a gem. It comes across in this production as a mix of Burlesque and Hellzapoppin. Yes it is amusing and entertaining as a staged production. Yes the ballet of the frogs and the the naiad Platee danced by male Paul Agnew is skillfully done. The story line is supposed to be humorous: Jupiter in order to play a trick on his ever jealous wife Juno descends to earth to be charmed by the ugliest of females; the naiad Platee. She is dainty and demur, though a frog, and believes herself to be beautiful and desirable. As this is all a joke using her, ones feels somewhat sorry for the innocent creature.I gave one star for the music for there are some excellent passages and one star for the chorus and corps de ballet for their delft work. All in all, however, it is silly and forgettable. Just play the music without translation, it is gem material.

reviewText: Enough has been written about the details so let me just say I found this absolutely delightful.  Early music rarely holds my interest for long but this was definitely an exception.  My only complaint is with the titles.  The translation was such that I did not have a clue most of the time as to what was happening on stage.  After Act 1, I found a synopsis online.  As is usual with Kultur, none came with the DVD.  That aside, I would highly recommend this performance.
summary: Better than I could have ever expected

reviewText: While I am not generally enthusiastic about "moderne" updates of baroqueworks, there's something about Rameau that really lends itself to contemporary re-thinking;  maybe it's the sheer sense of JOY and humanityof the music that makes it work.This production of Platee is marvelous--- the conducting, playing and(most of the) singing are first-rate. And, most important to this type of production, the cast is made up of first-rate singing ACTORS, whose fresh and vibrant personalities are immensely appealing. I found myself watchingwith an ear-to-ear smile throughout most every scene, so enchanting are the characterizations of everyone on stage.(The Act 1 scenes with Platee, Mercury and Kithaeron are a total delight).The direction and choreography are, with a few exceptions, amazingly inventive. (You want brake-dancing frogs?...you GOT 'em!) Even the little cross-over in Act 3 with the man/dog on the leash to Rameau's sublime musette has a mystique and magic of its own.The spirit of Rameau's music is contagious...especially when brought to life with such brilliance.

reviewText: I enjoyed this opera.  It was nothing like I had expected and it was also clear that the performers enjoyed putting on this performance.  The ballet was particularly enjoyable.  The costumes and the sets worked for me.I have to agree with other reviewers who panned the Kultur dvd.  I've other recordings from Kultur that seem much better, but this was just too dark. The lack of subtitles in any other language seems very strange too.  As for no text of any sort (this has happened before with Kultur dvd's), that I easily solved with a printout from Wikipedia but I don't see why I should have had to do that.I will seriously take the matter of brand labels into consideration in the future.  Hopefully the firm takes constructive criticism seriously and they will remedy the shortfalls of this dvd in the future.
summary: An enjoyable work, a mediocre dvd

reviewText: Rameau's operas became some kind of seldom seen event in opera houses outside France; and perhaps even there, it might be argued. Not any more as it looks, as there seems to be a kind of Rameau come back in recent years that not only has prompted a few opera houses in Europe to stage some of his works, it appears to have also crossed the Atlantic if the NYC Opera's revival of this same work is a signal.With a rather silly plot of the gods playing a cruel practical joke on an ugly and plain marsh nymph who bears the work's title as her name, it is one of the few comedies composed by Rameau, who for much of his stage output stuck to the usual tragedie in vogue in France since Lully's time. It is very cleverly staged in this version from the Opera Garnier in Paris and features an outstanding performance by scotsman Paul Agnew who not only sings his drag role very well but proves to be a remarkable actor too. Mireille Delunsch acquits herself highly, too, and despatches the difficult aria that closes the first act with flair and ease. Naouri proves his usual efficacy as the satyr yet some aloofness is not absent from the interpretation.Apart from Agnew, the evening's other great stars are Minkowski and his outstanding Musiciens du Louvre, a delight to anyone with an ear for late french baroque music and its sonorities. Minkowski is an expert in this repertoire and already has in his CV a (sound only) recording of the piece with an altogether different cast that dates from some 15 years ago. He again conducts the work with great care and enjoyment and he and his musicians participate with theatrical flair in some comical episodes where characters invade the pit.As is too common in US releases of this kind, information provided the customer in the box is virtually nonexistant, not even a plot synopsis but merely a list of chapters in the single-leaf insert. The programme itself has no additional material. For these two reasons, and because the stage conception might not suit all tastes this side of the Atlantic, I award only four stars to this DVD, in spite of the performance probably meriting the fifth in its own terms.

reviewText: Update: Now there is a newer edition from ArthausPlatee. Enjoy!-----------Other reviewers have praised this performance in depth, so I won't repeat what was already said. Jean-Philippe Rameau's Platée, or Junon jalouse, was written in 1745, half way betweenCastor Et Pollux(1739) andZoroastre(1749). As with his other comédie lyriqueLes Paladins, it is in 3 acts, perhaps influenced by the Italian models. (On the other hand, Rameau's tragédies en musique are usually in 5 acts, following the tradition set by Jean-Baptiste Lully.) Laurent Pelly's splendidly imaginative production is matched by good singing and acting from the cast: Paul Agnew in the title (skirt) role is as good as he ever has been. Laurent Naouri brings to the role Cithéron uncanny sense of comedy et une voix magnifique. Mireille Delunsch's La Folie (Folly) almost brought the house down in her long "aria" in Act II! However, the most remarkable contribution comes from Marc Minkowski's direction and Musiciens du Louvre-Grenoble is sparkling throughout.Grenoble, where the Musiciens du Louvre-Grenoble is based and Université Joseph Fourier is located, is an Alpine town near Lyon. (In fact, 2011 marks the 200th anniversary of the Université and I will be there for celebration.) Since I was thoroughly impressed by the group both live and on DVDs, I had to get this Platée. Now the bad news: After the really good presentation of the 6 Rameau DVDs from Opus Arte,(*) Kultur's low quality presentation of the Platée is a big let-down. Furthermore, the TDK PAL release recommended by other reviewers are no longer available. Fortunately, there is an NTSC all-region version of the TDK release available from the famous auction site, for around $20 when this review is being written. (A link is given in the Comment below.)That officially licensed Taiwanese edition is, as said earlier, in essence the TDK edition, but in the NTSC all-region format. It comes with 2 DVDs, one in dual-layer DVD-9 and the second in single-layer DVD-5 (instead of 1 DVD in Kultur edition). The extra disc allows for better video and superior sound quality. Indeed, it includes 3 sound tracks: uncompressed PCM, Dolby Digital 5.1 and DTS 5.1 (instead of Kultur's compressed Dolby Digital stereo only. Argh.) The subtitles are only available in English and traditional Chinese, but the English subtitle here is much better than Kultur's skimpy and off-and-on English subtitle. In addition, it has a fully illustrated 24-page booklet on the cast, the composer and the work, and a detailed synopsis, all in English and traditional Chinese.This sparkling performance is highly recommended, but only in the (officially licensed) Taiwanese edition or TDK PAL release if can still get one.P.S. In case you are curious where my Kultur DVD has gone. Don't worry. It has found a new home in a graduate student's flat after I got the Taiwanese edition!----------------------(*) The 6 Opus Arte Rameau DVDs, mostly from Paris Opera and DNO, are:Rameau - Les Boreades,Rameau - Les Indes Galantes,Rameau - Les Paladins,Rameau - Castor Et Pollux,Rameau - Zoroastre,Rameau - Motet 'In Convertendo'  Pièces de Clavecin en concert (Saint-Louis des Invalides Church, 2004) / documentary 'The Real Rameau' (2004)
summary: Splendid performance, but get a better edition!
